Articles.Content:
This should probably be in questions and tutorials.

I consider three scenarios:

-First stage, initial TWR 1.2, atmospheric

-Upper stage, initial TWR 1.2, vacuum

I'd lean towards 0.5 atm for lower stages, or 0.2 atm if you're building SSTO rockets. I would also argue that it's more important to consider payload mass relative to launcher mass (and cost). That said, within the constraints you were aiming for, it looks like a good analysis.

This should probably be in questions and tutorials.

I'd lean towards 0.5 atm for lower stages, or 0.2 atm if you're building SSTO rockets. I would also argue that it's more important to consider payload mass relative to launcher mass (and cost). That said, within the constraints you were aiming for, it looks like a good analysis.

Makes sense. I added a chart at an average of 0.6 atmospheres. I seem to either drop first stages early, or late. If a first stage is dropped late, the 0 ATM table is probably better anyway.

In this chart the big loser is the aerospike.

And people say the NASA Engines aren't OP.... I'm glad I nerfed mine, I felt bad using them. Also, it's not necessarily that the KW Engines are weak, more that they are balanced with the engine stats from 0.23... Which, you know, didn't have lifter engines with nearly the same efficieny as Vac engines.

I'd love to see you get 22km/s of dV out of a KR2-L though... Or even 25km/s out of a NTR! Every engine has a max dV, so you may need to factor that into your calculations; also, are you factoring in engine and tank weight into your dV calcs? Just making sure you get it right, this is a useful chart.

And people say the NASA Engines aren't OP.... I'm glad I nerfed mine, I felt bad using them. Also, it's not necessarily that the KW Engines are weak, more that they are balanced with the engine stats from 0.23... Which, you know, didn't have lifter engines with nearly the same efficieny as Vac engines.

I'd love to see you get 22km/s of dV out of a KR2-L though... Or even 25km/s out of a NTR! Every engine has a max dV, so you may need to factor that into your calculations; also, are you factoring in engine and tank weight into your dV calcs? Just making sure you get it right, this is a useful chart.

Think the NASA engines are designed more so average players can do asteroid redirect or Jool missions without going crazy with asparagus.

Back in 0.23 I was not able to build an practical SSTO rocket, that is outside 48-7S and probe. With 0.235 its easy, 1x2 and two orange tanks on side and you have an nice light lifter for an 3 man pod or a 4 ton payload. 24x4 is 18 ton, 40 with SRB help, this is my workhorse, an 0.235 version with 7 24x4 was able to lift 100 ton to orbit, 200 ton with SRB.

All of this was designed to return to space center.

And people say the NASA Engines aren't OP.... I'm glad I nerfed mine, I felt bad using them. Also, it's not necessarily that the KW Engines are weak, more that they are balanced with the engine stats from 0.23... Which, you know, didn't have lifter engines with nearly the same efficieny as Vac engines.

I'd love to see you get 22km/s of dV out of a KR2-L though... Or even 25km/s out of a NTR! Every engine has a max dV, so you may need to factor that into your calculations; also, are you factoring in engine and tank weight into your dV calcs? Just making sure you get it right, this is a useful chart.

No, for simplicity I disregarded tank weight. That's why the dVs listed were impossibly high. Basically, I was lazy.

I have gone back and updated the charts to reflect the structure mass of fuel tanks. I used 0.22 for RCS since that is the number used by procedural parts. The aerospike went up a few notches in the 1atm chart

The computed numbers can now be easily checked by building a tank+engine and seeing what MechJeb says the dV is. I did a few just to be sure.

Edited December 15, 2014 by Virindi

I've never understood the needing NASA engines for a practical SSTO argument. A 0.21-0.23.5 Skipper (which was distinctly underpowered) plus an orange tank could reliably get up to 3.5 tonnes into LKO. Not reusable, but then there were no funds at the time. A cluster of aerospikes can also be viable as a reusable rocket SSTO.
What's the structure ratio on the big KW monoprop tanks? The KW SPS might do better if you can give it a better tank.

What's the structure ratio on the big KW monoprop tanks? The KW SPS might do better if you can give it a better tank.

Fair point. I added a table of RCS engines by RCS tank used; they vary from 0.111 (B9 tanks) to 0.319 (Squad round radial tank). The only tank with which the HSPS is any good* is the Squad 2.5m tank (0.1176). The HSPS sucks with KW's own tanks (0.273).

With the Squad 2.5 tank, and only that tank, the HSPS is a good orbital engine achieving 8052 maximum deltav @0.2 vac. That's 4th place after the LV-N, the Vesta VR-1, and the B9 VTOL rocket engine.

The KW 2.5 and 3.75m tanks should probably be changed to a ratio of 0.11765 to match the Squad 2.5.

*This is assuming you don't want to make a ship with a billion radial B9 tanks (and possibly fuel lines if not using crossfeed enabler).

Edited December 16, 2014 by Virindi

Added Novapunch engines.

I just noticed that the Novapunch aerospike has thrust vectoring and an alternator...sheesh. A cluster of those would make an amazing first stage powerplant.
